context: Among higher alcohols determined, all the strains produced 3-methyl-1-butanol (Fig. 1 ), that is the major higher alcohol in wine (Romano et al., 2003; Garde-Cerdán and Ancín-Azpilicueta, 2007). 2-Methyl-1-propanol, 2-methyl-1-butanol, and 2-phenylethanol were recovered in numerous experimental wines; in particular, about 65% of the wines produced by fermentation with “Southern” strains were characterized by the presence of these three higher alcohols, whereas only 30% of wines produced by “Northern” strains contained these compounds. Two wines, samples 9 and 10, produced by fermentation with two different S. cerevisiae “Southern” strains, didn't contain these compounds. 1-Propanol was detected in 15 of 20 wines fermented with S. cerevisiae “Southern” strains, while only 6 of 16 wines produced by “Northern” yeasts contained this compound (Fig. 1). The content of this higher alcohol in wine is mainly influenced by the starter strain responsible for the fermentation (Giudici et al., 1993; Torrea et al., 2003). The content of other alcohols was variable in all the wine samples without correlation with the strain origin. As regards acid content of the experimental wines, these compounds were not recovered only in five wines (samples 3, 6, 10, 15, and 18) obtained by fermentation with “Southern” strains and were not determined in all the experimental wines derived by fermentation with “Northern” strains.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, sulfur dioxide is not directly mentioned in relation to 1-propanol. The focus is on the production of various higher alcohols, including 1-propanol, during the fermentation of wines by different strains of S. cerevisiae. While sulfur dioxide is commonly used in winemaking as a preservative and antioxidant, its specific interaction with 1-propanol or its influence on its production is not discussed in the provided text.
